review.title: A tentative model for dimensionless phoneme distance from binary distinctive features
review.abstract: This work proposes a tentative model for the calculation of dimensionless distances between phonemes; sounds are described with binary distinctive features and distances show linear consistency in terms of such features. The model can be used as a scoring function for local and global pairwise alignment of phoneme sequences, and the distances can be used as prior probabilities for Bayesian analyses on the phylogenetic relationship between languages, particularly for cognate identification in cases where no empirical prior probability is available.

sections.heading: 1.2 The new and tentative model
sections.text: The model presented here is part of a larger project to apply quantitative methods to historical linguistics; one of its objectives is to estimate the probability of phonemes representing ancestral states. The model was developed on the basis of the following guidelines: • The distances between phonemes are expressed on a dimensionless scale between 0.0, the score for comparing a phoneme with itself and 1.0, the maximum possible score within the model; • the model enables the comparison of different phonemes with a zero state (i.e., without sound), which allows the quantification of the production and cancellation of sound; • there is a unique model for all phonemes, without separate models for separate sound classes; • Without taking into account disputed phonemes or phonemes with extremely marginal presence in the inventories, the model covers all theoretical possible phonemes, including non-pulmonic and laryngeal consonants; • the model is based on a single set of binary distinction features that can be expanded later on individual phonemes with the help of D.

sections.heading: 3 Alignment
sections.text: Algorithms for word alignment and recognition, such as those used in LingPy, can be extended with the distances shown here. The tables below show the values of the matrix, which are provided with a number of corresponding sets from LingPy tests, attempting to mimic the results of LingPy.

sections.heading: 4 Discussion and future work
sections.text: According to a common aphorism in statistics attributed to George Box, all models are wrong, but some are useful. Certainly, the first part of the aphorism applies to the model presented here: apart from the inevitable shortcomings of a universal model based on the abstract concept of the "phoneme," the final matrix has a number of limitations, such as the omission of tones and suprasegmental characteristics and an inconsistent treatment of phonemes. Indeed, this is a significant limitation of the matrix, while diphthongs are not. An even more consistent objection is that a uniform model is offered for applications in which two evaluation models are expected and needed.
